text: Shutter speed is the amount of time the camera's shutter is open. A fast shutter speed (like 1/1000s) freezes motion, while a slow shutter speed (like 1/30s) captures blur and movement. The pinwheel shows how fast and slow shutter speeds create different visual effects.

Fast shutter: ideal for freezing moments, like the intense moments of athletes competing. Slow shutter: typically used to capture motion, such as a starry night or a flowing waterfall. The right shutter speed can balance both freezing the moment and capturing motion in a single photo.
